com.ojcoleman.ahni.experiments.csb

Class StaticTransformEnvironment

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.ojcoleman.ahni.experiments.csb.Environment
      • com.ojcoleman.ahni.experiments.csb.SimpleNavigationEnvironment
        • com.ojcoleman.ahni.experiments.csb.StaticTransformEnvironment
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Configurable

    public class StaticTransformEnvironment
extends SimpleNavigationEnvironment

    An environment which uses arbitrary functions to transform signals to and from the environment state. One function transforms the output vector from the agent into changes to the environments state and another is used to transform the current state into an input vector for the agent (ie it generates the agents perception of the current environment state). The input transform is used to generate a delta vector which represents a (relatively small) change in the environment state. This function is generated such that it is possible to create a positive and negative value for each output from the function corresponding to each dimension of the environment state. Thus, via this transform, the agent can move around within the Cartesian space represented by the environment state space.

    Note that the input and output vector sizes do not need to match the size of the vector representing the environment state. The transforms may be highly non-linear. The transform functions are implemented with AnjiNet neural networks in a feed-forward function. The functions are composed of randomly selected and connected nodes which represent a single mathematical function, such as Sigmoid, multiply, inverse, absolute, etc. Increasing the difficulty of the environment increases the number of nodes in the network and/or the in-degree of connections for each node.

    The reward signal, which is a function of the Euclidean distance from the current environment state to the goal state, is provided directly to the agent.

    Environments can optionally have (hyper-)spherical obstacles added at random locations (increasing the environment difficulty increases the number of obstacles). The agent cannot directly perceive the obstacles. If the environment size (dimensionality) is 2 then the images generated by RLContinuousStateBased will include the obstacle locations.

      int getInputSize()
      Returns the input size of the environment, the output of the agent is generally input directly to the environment, thus the agent output vector size would usually be equal to this.

    • Field Detail

      • OUTPUT_SIZE

        public static final java.lang.String OUTPUT_SIZE
        The size of the output vector. Defaults to fitness.function.rlcss.size + 1 (ie environment state size plus a reinforcement signal). The last value in the output vector is always the reinforcement signal and isn't affected by the state to output transform function.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • INPUT_SIZE

        public static final java.lang.String INPUT_SIZE
        The size of the input vector. Defaults to fitness.function.rlcss.size.

        Constant Field Values

      • logToImage

        public void logToImage(java.lang.String baseFileName,
              int imageSize)
        Optionally allow rendering the environment configuration to an image or images. This method is called once for a set of trials. Implementations must handle creating the images and saving them to disk. This implementation renders the obstacles in the environment iff the environment size (dimensions) == 2. Renders the input and output transforms of the environment.
        Overrides:
        logToImage in class SimpleNavigationEnvironment
        Parameters:
        baseFileName - The directory and base file name to use for the images saved to disk.
        imageSize - The (suggested) image size.
